Tel: +86 0592 2183088 The local environment of framework Ti determines the catalytic properties of titanium silicalites (TS-1) for olefin epoxidation. As for the Au/TS-1 catalyst toward vapor phased propylene epoxidation with H2/O2, regulating the framework Ti site from the Au-Ti integration level remains difficult due to the lack of Au-Ti interfacial interaction. To address this issue, an Au-Ti integrated catalyst with a zeolite encapsulation structure was first proposed herein via in situ solvent-free synthesis, exploiting tannic acid as functional agent to anchor the bifunctional components. The as-prepared an-Au@TS-1 catalyst features highly dispersed and integrated Au-Ti active sites, as mutually confirmed by HR-TEM, ICP and UV-vis. Thus, the Au-Ti interfacial interaction is enhanced to regulate the Ti-O-Si micro-environment, thus improving the electronic-positivity of framework Ti to stabilize the active species. Such crucial regulation effects were stepwise elucidated by mutually complementary characterizations including X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS), adsorption infrared spectra (IR), Raman spectroscopy, X-ray near edge structure (XANES) and density functional theory (DFT) simulations. As anticipated, the integrated catalyst an-Au@TS-1 exhibits a concomitant increment in PO selectivity (90.2%) and H2 efficiency (26.7%). The methodology and insights stated herein could guide the rational optimization of Au-Ti catalysts and help unravel the role of tannic acid assisted strategies for various integrated catalyst preparations. Graphic Abstract The Au-Ti integrated catalyst features highly integrated bifunctional sites to manipulate the local environment of Ti site via Au-Ti interfacial interaction, facilitating to boost the activity toward propylene epoxidation with H2/O2. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Titanium silicalite (TS-1) local environment of framework Ti integration catalyst vapor phased propylene epoxidation tannic acid Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Due to the growing industrial demand of chemical reagents, the catalytic selective oxidation of organic substrate to their corresponding oxide product embodies prime scientific and engineering importance [1]. Typical oxidation processes include olefin epoxidation [2], sulfide oxidation [3], alcohol oxidation [4–5], ketone ammoximation [6] and so forth [7]. These reactions usually exploit hydroperoxide species (liquid H2O2 or HOO* species from vapor H2/O2) as the oxidant and transition metal-containing compound as the catalyst [1-2,7]. Of these, vapor phased propylene epoxidation under H2/O2 has become a research hotspot owing to its superior environment-benignity and atom-economy [8–10]. This reaction exploits titanium silicalite-1 (TS-1) supporting Au as bifunctional catalyst [11–15]. During the catalytic process, Au first activates H2/O2 to generate HOO* species, and then framework Ti coordinates with them to yield Ti-OOH active species that eventually epoxidize C=C [14–16]. However, such pivotal Ti-OOH species are subject to severe decomposition under high temperature reaction atmosphere [17–19], which limits the improvement of catalytic properties to meet the industrial requirements [20]. Fundamentally, the formation and transfer of Ti-OOH necessitate Au and Ti active sites to work in a cooperative manner[11-13,15,21-22]. Furthermore, the reactivity of Ti-OOH is principally determined by the coordination state, electron density and spatial structure of framework Ti, which is the local environment of framework Ti [18,23-25]. Thus, to fundamentally improve the performances of Au-Ti catalyst, it is necessary to regulate the local environment of Ti site from the Au-Ti integration level. In the widely-used Au/TS-1 catalyst, TS-1 is first synthesized via hydrothermal, dry-gel, solvent-free approaches [19,26-27], and subsequently Au NPs are supported through sol-immobilization (SI), deposition-precipitation (DP) and impregnation (IM) methods [11-12,14,28]. In these preparations, the Au NPs might immobilize adjacent to Ti sites due to the electrostatic-force interaction [29]. The particle size of metal is much larger than the pore size of zeolite, and thus Au NPs would mostly distribute on the surface of TS-1, due to the lack of contact with Ti sites inside the micro-pores [30]. To address this issue, some researchers carried out useful attempts: Yang et al. synthesized an encapsulated catalyst of Au/TiO2@SBA-15 with a TiO2 layer oriented deposited around Au NPs [31]. Tsang et al. proposed a K+-mediated IM method, that promotes Au clusters into the micro-pores of TS-1 in vicinity of Ti sites [22]. However, these as-prepared catalysts realized limited performance increments toward propylene epoxidation under H2/O2. That is, it is difficult to modulate Ti sites by simply improving the geometric contact between Au and Ti sites. In light of these, a facile and definite Au-Ti anchoring strategy is required to construct the Au-Ti integrated catalyst and modulate the environment of Ti site. Furthermore, based on the classical support-metal interaction (SMSI) theory, the reinforced charge-transfer interaction between the metal and the oxide support could in turn regulate the nature of the metal or the support [32–40]. The latter situation usually occurs by sharing interfacial oxygen atoms on the support [37-38,40]. In the case of TS-1 zeolite, the Ti site combined with its neighboring Si-O bond amounts to the local environment of framework Ti, which in turn determines the catalytic nature of TS-1 [23,41-42]. In other words, the Au-Ti integrated catalyst with enhanced Au-(O)-Ti interaction could afford to have attractive possibilities to regulate the Ti-O-Si local environment. In our previous study, a poly-phenol mediated anchoring protocol was first proposed to construct an Au-Ti integrated catalyst, in which TS-1 is anchored to grow adjacent to Au and generate a sandwich-type structure (Au/S-1/TS-1) [15]. The electronic structure of Au NPs was thus modulated via enhanced Au-Ti integration, to improve the generation of HOO* species on Au NPs. To modulate the Ti sites herein, a more efficient anchoring agent is needed to completely integrate Ti sites with Au NPs [43–44]. Furthermore, such multilayer structure of catalyst should be further optimized to homogeneously distribute Au-Ti integrated sites in the whole catalyst [15,30]. Herein, an Au-Ti integrated catalyst with homogeneous encapsulation structure was innovatively reported. The catalyst was fabricated by a tannic acid (TA)-assisted in situ solvent-free synthesis (termed an-Au@TS-1). TA with abundant phenol groups plays reducing and coordinating roles to anchor Au-Ti components, thus rendering Au-Ti active sites highly integrated and dispersed in the catalyst. The local environment of Ti sites was thus regulated by the enhanced Au-(O)-Ti interfacial interaction. The structural properties of an-Au@TS-1 were characterized by comprehensive measurements, to understand the mechanism of Au-Ti integration effect due to TA. Moreover, the Lewis acid of an-Au@TS-1 was selected as a representative descriptor to elucidate the local environment of Ti sites, evaluated by acetonitrile sorption infrared spectra (IR). The impact of Au-Ti integration upon the local environment of Ti sites was first explored from the molecular level, using density functional theory (DFT) simulations, X-ray near edge structure (XANES) and Raman spectroscopy. The catalytic properties of an-Au@TS-1 were evaluated toward vapor phased propylene epoxidation with H2/O2. This study opens an unprecedented and sustainable methodology for preparing Au-Ti integrated catalyst toward propylene epoxidation. Novel metal-hetero atom zeolite integrated catalyst systems are expected from it, thus leading to other catalytic oxidation applications. Meanwhile, this work can help to explain the catalytic mechanism of vapor phased epoxidation, properly grasping the essence of “tuning the hydroperoxide active species” in terms of the role of Au-Ti integration. 2 Experimental Section 2.1 Materials Titanium bis (ammonium lactate) dihydroxy (Ti-BALDH, 50 wt% aq. soln.) was bought from Alfa Aesar. Tannic acid (TA) was purchased from Macklin Biochemical Co. Ltd, Shanghai. Ionic liquid [BMIM][BF4] (99.9%) was bought from Cheng Jie Chemical, Co. Ltd., Shanghai. Tetrapropyl ammonium hydroxide (TPAOH, 40 wt% aq. soln.) was provided by Cainorise Chemical Co., Ltd., Shanghai. Fumed silica (SiO2, HL-200, SBET = 200 ± 20 m2/g) was obtained from GBS Technology Co. Ltd., Guangzhou. Chloroauric acid (HAuCl4·4H2O, 99.9%) as well as acetonitrile was produced by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd., China. Typically, 1 g HAuCl4·4H2O dissolved in 50 mL DI water gave rise to the Au3+ precursor solution, with a concentration of 0.04856 mol/L for usage. 2.2 Preparation of pre-integrate precursor The pre-integrate precursor Au-Ti/SiO2 was prepared by sol-immobilization (SI) method using TA as reducing agent [15,28]. As a typical run with Au loading of 0.5 wt% and Si/Ti molar ratio of 50: 260 μL Au3+ precursor solution (0.04856 mol/L) was dropped into 50 mL TA solution (0.3 g/L) under stirring for 20 min at room temperature. Thereafter, 0.098 μL Ti-BALDH was incorporated into the resulted purple-colored Au0 NPs sol to pre-integrated with Au NPs. Finally, 0.5 g fumed silica along with 100 μL ionic liquid [BMIM][BF4] was added for another 20 min of ambient stirring, to obtain the pre-integrate precursor Au-Ti/SiO2. Additionally, Au/SiO2 was synthesized under nearly identical conditions except for the inclusion of Ti-BALDH, for the preparation of control sample un-Au@TS-1. Notably, [BMIM][BF4] helps the reducing agent (TA) to immobilize Au NPs onto solid supports, realizing close to 100% capture efficiency of Au [28]. 2.3 Preparation of integrated catalyst The integrated catalyst an-Au@TS-1 was fabricated by in situ solvent-free crystallization method using Au-Ti/SiO2 as silica and titanium sources [45–47]. As a typical run with Au loading of 0.5 wt% and Si/Ti molar ratio of 50: 1 g Au-Ti/SiO2 was ground with 1.2 g TPAOH and 0.08 g silicalite-1 (S-1) seeds to serve as the raw material, for the subsequent thermal crystallization process (180 °C, 96 h). Then, the resultant crystal powder after careful rinsing was subject to aerobic calcination (550 °C, 5 h) with a heating rate of 1 °C/min, to obtain the final catalyst. Moreover, the utilized S-1 seed was also solvent-freely synthesized according to literature report [48]. 2.4 Preparation of control catalysts For comparative purpose, the encapsulated catalyst un-Au@TS-1 was similarly prepared vis in situ solvent-free method as stated above, in which 0.098 μL Ti-BALDH was ground with 1 g Au/SiO2, 1.2 g TPAOH and 0.08 g S-1 seed to serve as raw material. On the other hand, the supported catalyst Au/TS-1 was prepared by SI method, using TA as reducing agent. And, the used TS-1 support was also synthesized by solvent-free method, as described in literature [45]. In detail, 260 μL Au3+ precursor solution was added into 50 mL TA solution (0.3 g/L) under ambient stirring for 20 min. Then, 0.5 g TS-1 zeolite (Si/Ti, 50) along with 100 μL[BMIM][BF4] was incorporated for another 20 min of stirring, to immobilize Au NPs upon TS-1 support. The resulted powder after careful rinsing was subject to aerobic calcination (550 °C, 5 h) with a heating rate of 1 °C/min, to obtain the final supported catalyst. Note that the Au loadings and Si/Ti molar ratios of control samples are identical to those of an-Au@TS-1. 2.5 Characterizations X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed on a diffractometer (Ultima IV, Rigaku, Japan) with CuKα radiation, from 0.5 to 80o. The Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra was recorded on a spectrometer (Nicolet N6700, Thermo, USA) from 400 to 4000 cm−1 with a resolution of 4 cm−1. The diffuse reflectance ultraviolet-visible spectra (DR UV-vis) were measured by a spectrometer (Carry 5000, Varian, USA) from 200 to 800 nm, utilizing BaSO4 as reference. The nitrogen sorption isotherms were monitored by a sorption analyzer (ASAP 2000, Micromeritics, USA). The catalyst sample was subject to thermal pretreatment on vacuum (300 °C, 10−2 Pa) for 3 h prior to measurements. The inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectra (ICP-OES) was evaluated on a spectrometer (Agilent 5110, Agilent, USA). Certain amount of sample was digested in strong acid before evaluation. The ultraviolet-visible spectra (UV-vis) were recorded along with a spectrometer (EVOLUTION 220, Thermo, USA) from 200 to 800 nm. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was carried out on a microscope (ZEISS Sigma, ZEIS, Germany). The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution TEM (HR-TEM) were conducted by a microscope (TECNAI F30, Philips, the Netherlands). Size-distribution of Au NPs were calculated on the basis of at least 150 particles using Nano Measure Software. The X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were characterized by an XPS system (ESCALAB 250, Thermo, USA) with Al Kα X-ray source (1486.6 eV photons). All the binding energy values were referenced by 284.8 eV of C1s. The Raman spectra were collected by a spectrometer (inVia, Renishaw, UK) with a He-Ne laser output (532 nm, 100%). The X-ray adsorption spectra were collected at BL07A1 beamline (National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Taiwan) with a double Si (111) crystal monochromator for energy selection. The X-ray near edge structure (XANES) was measured at the Au LIII edge, and corresponding data analysis was obtained utilizing Athena Software. The acetonitrile sorption spectra were recorded on a spectrometer (Nicolet N6700, Thermo, USA) with MCT detector, in which a diffuse reflectance reaction chamber (PRAYING MANTISTM, Harrick, USA) was applied. The sample powder was placed on the steel mesh of sample cell, followed by dehydration pretreatment in N2 flow for 1 h (300 °C, 100 mL/min). Then, the background spectra of sample at 40, 60, 80, 100, 120 °C were collected as the temperatures progressively decreased from 300 to 25 oC. Afterwards, the acetonitrile vapor was fed into the chamber with N2 flow (25 °C, 80 mL/min) for 45 min adsorption, to record the adsorption spectrum of sample. At last, another N2 flow (60 mL/min) was fed into the chamber for 25 min desorption at corresponding temperatures (40, 60, 80, 100, 120 °C), to visualize the desorption spectrum of sample. 2.6 Catalytic evaluation The catalytic properties of vapor phased propylene epoxidation were evaluated on a fixed-bed reactor using 0.15 g catalyst at 300°C, with a feed gas of C3H6/O2/H2/N2=1:1:1:7 in volume and a space velocity of 7000 mL/gcat·h. Gaseous products and remaining reactants were monitored online by two sets of gas chromatograph (GC, GC9160, Xiamen Kefen Technology Co., Ltd, China) utilizing N2 and Ar as carrier gas, respectively. GC with thermal conductivity detector (TCD) using a 5A packed column (2mm×4m, 0.15 MPa, 150℃, Huaai. Inc.) detected the (moles of H2 fed-in) and (moles of H2 fed-out), while GC with flame ionization detector (FID) using free fatty acid phase (FFAP) capillary column (0.53mm×50m, 0.04 MPa, 60 °C, APPARATUS, Inc.) detected the (moles of products) including ethanol (Et), propylene oxide (PO), propane (Pr), acetone (An), acrolein (Ac) and (moles of C3H6 fed-out). Catalytic apparatus was illustrated in Supplementary Material, refers to Scheme S1. The catalytical performances of catalysts were determined following the equations below: C 3 H 6 Conversion = mol of ( PO ) + mol of ( P r ) + 2 / 3 × mol of ( Et ) + mol of ( An ) + mol of ( Ac ) mol of ( PO ) + mol of ( P r ) + 2 / 3 × mol of ( Et ) + mol of ( An ) + mol of ( Ac ) + mol of ( C 3 H 6 ) out PO Selectivity = mol of ( PO ) mol of ( PO ) + mol of ( P r ) + 2 / 3 × mol of ( Et ) + mol of ( An ) + mol of ( Ac ) , in which carbon numbers (such as 1, 1, 2/3, 1, 1) are used to calibrate the (moles of products). PO Yield = mol of PO per h per k g cat × molar weight of PO = Feed gas space − time velocity ( mL / g cat · h ) × fed − in C 3 H 6 partial pressure ( % ) × C 3 H 6 Conversion ( % ) × PO Selectivity ( % ) × 1 V m ( mol / mL ) × molar weight of PO ( g PO / mol ) in which feed gas space velocity is set to be 7000 mL/gcat·h herein, fed-in C3H6 partial pressure is set to be 1/10 herein (C3H6/O2/H2/N2=1:1:1:7 in volume of feed gas), Vm refers to the molar volume of gas. H 2 Efficiency = mol of ( PO ) mol of ( H 2 ) in − mol of ( H 2 ) out Note that the carbon balances in vapor phased propylene epoxidation with H2/O2 reach 100±5% [10,14,29]. The value of (moles of all products detected) was considered to represent the amount of consumed C3H6, in calculation of C3H6 conversion. PO yield is usually defined as a mass-specific activity indicator, related to the feed gas space velocity ( mL / g cat · h ), conversion of propylene (%) and selectivity of PO (%) [9,16-17]. H2 efficiency aims at evaluating the availability of H2 in contribution to generate PO, thereby using (moles of PO) as numerator in formula. Additionally, the peak area of product from GC signal should be calibrated by carbon number and correction factor, to acquire the realistic moles of product. Detailed explanation concerning the calculation of catalytic performance indexes could be found in Supplementary Material, refers to Scheme S1 and its note. 2.7 DFT simulations DFT simulations were carried out by means of Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP). The catalyst models were constructed along with Material Studio software. Charge density difference was accomplished using VESTA software. Lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) energy was selected to evaluate the Lewis acidity of the catalyst model, which could be directly obtained from the OUTCAR output file. The exchange-correlation energy was defined by the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerh (PBE) version. The cut-off energy was set as 400 eV for the plane wave basis. Atomic pseudopotentials were obtained based on the Projector Augmented Wave (PAW) method. The conjugated gradient method was used to optimize the structure. Furthermore, the convergence thresholds of energy and force were all set to 10−6 eV and 0.02 eV/Å, respectively. Brillouin zone integration has been performed on a 4×4×1 Monkhorst-Pack grid for structure optimization and 3×3×3 for static self-consistent field calculation of electronic structures. 3 Results and Discussion 3.1 Preparation and properties of an-Au@TS-1 To meticulously manipulate the framework Ti sites, tannic acid (TA) with abundant phenol groups was exploited to prepare the Au-Ti integrated catalyst, due to its excellent reducing ability of Au NPs and coordination ability with Ti precursor [15,43-44]. Fig. 1 shows the preparation process: as the inclusion of TA, Au NPs were reduced with massive phenol groups resided on the surfaces, and thus swiftly coordinated with Ti4+ to generate the Au-Ti pre-complex. Afterwards, the Au-Ti components were immobilized onto fumed silica (SiO2) via a TA-mediated sol-immobilization process. The Au-Ti/SiO2 precursor acting as titanium and silicon sources experienced an in situ solvent-free crystallization to prepare the final integrated catalyst anchoring-Au@TS-1 (abbreviated as an-Au@TS-1 throughout). Notably, the resulted catalyst assumes a uniform zeolite encapsulation structure, with encapsulated Au NPs combined with those inside framework Ti sites. There are still some external framework Ti sites distributed on the surface of the integrated catalyst. The extent would be discussed below in Section 3.5 Catalytic performances of an-Au@TS-1. For comparison, the control sample of un-Au@TS-1 was prepared in identical procedures except for the TA assisted-anchoring of Au-Ti components. The supported catalyst of Au/TS-1 was also prepared using only TA as a reductant. The morphologies of precursors (Au NPs, Au-Ti pre-complex, Au-Ti/SiO2 precursor) and final integrated catalyst an-Au@TS-1 could be clearly observed by HR-TEM photos (seen in Fig. S1 and Fig. 4). As shown in Fig. S1a and c, Ti4+ anchoring with Au NPs via a thin Ti-phenolic coating gives rise to the Au-Ti pre-complex. The Au NPs remain homogeneously dispersed during the precursor process, with the mean diameter ranging from 2.59 to 2.98 nm (Fig. S1). In particular, TA works as reducing and coordination agents in the preparation of an-Au@TS-1. As shown in Fig. S2a, the Au0 surface plasmon resonance band (SPR, ∼530 nm) and Ti-phenol ligand-to-metal charge transfer band (LMCT, 300∼400 nm) coexist in the UV vis spectra of Au-Ti pre-complex and Au-Ti/SiO2 precursor [44,49]. Moreover, the strong coordination interaction between TA and Ti4+ allows for the complete immobilization of Au-Ti pre-complex onto SiO2, as evidenced by the transparent supernatant of Au-Ti/SiO2 suspension (insert of Fig. S2a). The resulted supernatant of Au-Ti/SiO2 was further characterized using UV-vis. The supernatants of Au NPs and Au-Ti/SiO2 exhibit similar phenol residual composition derived from TA, as featured by their similar UV spectral characteristics (Fig. S2b). This situation was further confirmed by ICP-OES data (Tab. S1), in which Au-Ti/SiO2 exhibits Si/Ti molar ratios of 55 and Au loadings of 0.46 wt% close to the theoretical values (Si/Ti molar ratio, 50; Au loading, 0.5 wt%). Moreover, an-Au@TS-1 has nearly the same Si/Ti molar ratio and Au loading consistent with Au-Ti/SiO2 precursor, thus indicating the complete combination of Au and Ti in the final integrated catalyst. Above all, this TA-assisted anchoring strategy enables an intimate contact between Au and Ti components, which is beneficial for the integration of Au-Ti active sites in the final integrated catalyst. The structural properties of the as-prepared catalysts were investigated as below in Fig 2 . An-Au@TS-1, un-Au@TS-1, Au/TS-1 catalysts exhibit typical five-finger peaks (7.8°, 8.8°, 23.0°, 23.9° and 24.4°) in XRD patterns, ascribable to the MFI topology of titanium silicalites (Fig. 2a) [50]. Meanwhile, all samples show weak signal peaks at 38.2o indicative of Au NPs. However, un-Au@TS-1 displays a weak double-peak at 24.5o, suggesting a transition state from monoclinic to orthogonal structure for its TS-1 moiety [28,51]. Moreover, an-Au@TS-1, un-Au@TS-1, Au/TS-1 manifest similar FTIR bands, with 450, 800 and 1100 cm−1 ascribable to the bend stretch, symmetrical, anti-symmetrical stretching vibrations of [SiO4] units and 550, 1230 cm−1 attributable to the MFI framework. Notably, all samples present IR bands at 960 cm−1 corresponding to the Ti-O-Si bond of titanium silicalites (Fig. 2b) [28]. In detail, an-Au/TS-1 shows the highest amount of framework Ti species, identifiable by the least I550/I960 ratio value [52]. Accordingly, an-Au/TS-1 scarcely exhibit UV band of extra-framework Ti (∼330 nm) versus the other two control samples (Fig. 2c) [53]. Fig. 2d illustrates that all catalysts show Type IV isotherms with hysteresis loops, thus suggesting the presence of mesopores in line with the results of BJH pore-seize distributions (seen insert). In contrast, un-Au@TS-1 manifests inferior absorbed volume at low pressure (0<P/P0<0.01) and higher absorbed volume at high pressure (0.9<P/P0<1.0), indicating its defective zeolitic framework and uneven crystal size. As a result, an-Au@TS-1 and Au/TS-1 exhibit BET surface area (SBET) of 374 and 347 m2/g, respectively, typical of titanium silicalites (Tab. S2) [27,45]. However, un-Au@TS-1 exhibits a rather lower SBET of 304 m2/g. Collectively, an-Au@TS-1 presents better zeolitic framework architecture as opposed to the other control samples, which underscores the advantage of the Au-Ti anchoring strategy. 3.2 Morphology of an-Au@TS-1 The morphologies of the as-prepared catalysts were observed using SEM and TEM. As shown in Fig. 3 , all sapmles have a typical aggregation morphorlogy of titanium silicalites zeolites synthesized via solvent-freely method, which are composed of samll coffin-like crystal aggregations (150∼200 nm) [27,45,54-55]. However, un-Au@TS-1 assumes an irregular morphology with smaller particles (∼20 nm) dispersed upon zeolite crystal, representing a poor crystallization state of TS-1 moiety (Fig. 3b, e). Moreover, an-Au@TS-1 and TS-1 manifests consistent surface and bulk Si/Ti molar ratios, while un-Au@TS-1 exhibits deviation situation, as tabulated in Tab. S1. Such crystallization separation phenomenon in un-Au@TS-1 indicates an unbalanced hydrolysis of the Ti source [52]. This phenonemon mainly arises from the interference of Au NPs that don't have an anchoring relationship with Ti. The distribution of Au NPs was detected using HR-TEM. Initially, Au NPs could disperse uniformly in the Au-Ti pre-complex, Au-Ti/SiO2 and Au/SiO2 precursors (Fig. S1). However, this is not the case for the final catalysts. As present in Fig. 4 , Au NPs (∼2.44 nm) are uniformly encapsulated in the entire an-Au@TS-1 catalyst, whereas a considerable amount of Au NPs (∼2.87 nm) are embedded into small crystals aggregated upon the un-Au@TS-1 catalyst, which hints at an uneven Au-Ti integration state without the anchoring strategy. In the supported catalyst, the size of Au NPs markedly increases with a mean value of 4.19 nm due to the lack of zeolite encapsulation confinement [30,56]. Benefitng from the reducing and coordination abilities of TA, Ti sources could anchor with Au NPs in the form of a Ti-phenol compond [15,44,57-58], with the appearance of a light coating layer around Au NPs (Fig. S1c). This TA-based anchoring relationship not only improves Ti4+ to insert into the zeolitic framework site via solvent-free process [19], but also integrates Ti sites with Au NPs for enhanced interfacial interaction [15]. On the contrary, in the absence of anchoring strategy (such as un-Au@TS-1), Ti sites disperse randomly in the final catalyst, and only a few of Ti sites could interact with adjacent Au NPs. To summarize, the Au-Ti active sites of an-Au@TS-1 are highly dispersed and integrated at geometrical level with the asisstant of TA. This in turn enhances the Au-Ti electronic interaction to regulate the framework Ti site [15,38]. 3.3 Electronic structure of an-Au@TS-1 The electronic structures of Au-Ti active sites in the as-prepared catalysts were explored using XPS (Fig. 5 ). Au/TS-1 shows the metallic Au 4f7/2 signal at 84.0 eV [59], whereas an-Au/TS-1 and un-Au@TS-1 manifest a slightly oxidized Au 4f7/2 signal at 84.2 eV [40]. Meanwhile, the formation of Au-Ti integrated structure causes the Ti 3d3/2 signals to blue-shift to highest BEs (from 458.8 of Au/TS-1 eV to 460.0 eV of an-Au@TS-1). This situation represents the formation of tetrahedrally coordinated Ti species with the least charge-density in an-Au@TS-1 [60]. Additionally, the Ti 3d3/2 signal in un-Au@TS-1 is mixed including 458 eV of Au/TS-1 and 460 eV of an-Au@TS-1. Furthermore, it is well-known that the local environment of framework Ti in TS-1 (Ti-O-Si) plays a decisive role in the activity of catalytically active Ti-OOH species [18,23,25]. Thus, Raman spectroscopy was used to explore the Ti-O-Si structure in the as-prepared catalyst (Fig. 6 ). The Raman modes indicative of MFI topology are observed at 289 cm−1, 380 cm−1, and 815 cm−1 in all catalyst samples [62]. A signature of Ti-O-Ti aggregate at 144 cm−1 is found in Au/TS-1 and un-Au@TS-1, thus corresponding to the extra-framework Ti as mentioned above (Fig. 2) [63]. The characteristic Ti-O-Si bonds in titanium silicalites are formed as a result of Ti ion substitution, which consists of Ti-O bond and its neighboring perturbed Si-O bond. Their corresponding Raman signals are located at ∼490 cm−1, ∼530 cm−1, ∼1125 cm−1 and ∼960 cm−1 [62]. When excited by visible light (532 nm), the perturbed Si-O bond is more responsive to the Raman mode than the Ti-O bond [62–64]. Thus, the peak-shift for Si-O bond is selected herein to assess the local environment of Ti. In comparison to Au/TS-1, an-Au@TS-1 exhibits obvious red-shifted Raman signal (from 969 cm−1 to 956 cm−1), thus demonstrating the Si-O bonds with lower electron-density. Namely, the polarization degree of Si-Oδ−-Tiδ+ bond was reduced, followed by the formation of electron-loss framework Ti sites in the integrated catalysts [65–66]. For comparison, un-Au@TS-1 shows mixed Raman peaks of Si-O bond including 956 and 959 cm−1, which demonstrates that only some of the Ti sites exhibit lower electron-density. This situation agrees with the above XPS data. According to the classical SMSI theory, the migration of oxide onto metal NPs to form the encapsulation structure helps to induce the electron-transfer interaction between metal and oxide support [36–38]. This rationale also holds true for the zeolite encapsulation catalyst [39], which could account for the peak-shifts in XPS and Raman spectra for an-Au@TS-1. However, in the absence of a TA anchoring strategy, only part of the Ti sites could interact with the adjacent Au NPs, which exhibit transition states in XPS and Raman spectra for un-Au@TS-1. To distinguish the difference between an-Au@TS-1 and un-Au@TS-1, a more appropriate descriptor concerning the local environment of Ti site was considered, further explaining the influence of Au-Ti integration. Lewis acidity is an intrinsic property derived from the coordinative unsaturation of the Ti ion. It imparts superior catalytic abilities to the framework Ti of titanium silicalites [19,23,25,61], which theoretically depends on the different subsititution locations of Ti ions in the zeolite architecture [19,23,41]. In other words, the acidity is a typical manifestation to describe the local environment of Ti sites [41–42]. The acetonitrile sorption IR is shown in Fig. 7 . Instead of pyridine, acetonitrile with relatively weaker basicity was selected herein as a probe molecule to recognize different Lewis acidity values of framework Ti sites. Acetonitrile adsorbed on catalyst samples exhibit doublet IR bands located at 2253 cm−1 and 2294 cm−1 due to the Fermi resonance between CH3 and CN groups [67]. Importantly, acetonitrile molecules adsorbed on Lewis acidic Ti sites show a featured IR band at 2312 cm−1 [68], which could be seen in all catalyst samples (Fig. 7a-c). The adsorbed acetonitrile molecules gradually desorbed from the framework Ti sites as increasing desorption temperatures (from 40 to 120 oC), presenting a decline trend for IR intensity. The normalized ratio of I2312/I2294 was plotted as a function of desorption temperature, to quantitate the strength of Lewis acidity. Fig. 7d shows that un-Au@TS-1 along with Au/TS-1 demonstrates a similar decline trend in which the IR signal initially attenuates sharply and then steadily decreases. In contrast, the integrated catalyst exhibits a gentle downward trend as temperature increases. This is indicative of the enhanced Lewis acidity of an-Au@TS-1. The local environment of framework Ti in an-Au@TS-1 has been meticulously regulated following the integration of Au-Ti active sites. 3.4 Local environment of framework Ti in an-Au@TS-1 DFT simulations showed the effect of Au-Ti integration upon the local environment of framework Ti at the atomic level. Considering the absence of Au-Ti interaction in the supported catalyst (Au/TS-1) as evidenced above, the encapsulated catalysts an-Au@TS-1 and un-Au@TS-1 were investigated in the following analyses. The encapsulation structure was represented by a simplified model with Au12 cluster fixed into [TiSi30O34H56] TS-1 topology [30], as illustrated in Fig. S3. The Ti atom was substituted adjacent to Au12 in the an-Au@TS-1 model, and away from Au12 in the un-Au@TS-1 model. Meanwhile, Ti atoms were located at T6 site in both an-Au@TS-1 and un-Au@TS-1 models, because this site possessed special Lewis acidity versus other crystallographic sites [19]. Detailed modeling and optimization information could be found in the Supplementary Materials, refers to the note of Fig. S3. As present in Fig. 8 , the charge density differences were depicted to illustrate the electron-transfer between noble metal and zeolite matrix. Although the two encapsulated models exhibit similar charge distribution, the trend of Au NPs interacting with Ti ion via bridged oxygen atoms is more obvious in an-Au@TS-1 than that in un-Au@TS-1. This phenomenon reveals the form of electronic interaction between Au and Ti in the integrated catalyst of an-Au@TS-1. Moreover, the LUMO levels for an-Au@TS-1 and un-Au@TS-1 were calculated to be -2.6972 eV and -2.6527 eV, suggesting an improved Lewis acidity of an-Au@TS-1.19, 25 The acidic improvement could be assigned to the intensified perturbation to the local environment of Ti site (Ti-O-Si) [42,69], which results from the enhanced Au-(O)-Ti electronic interaction following Au-Ti integration. Density of state (DOS) was next determined within Au-O-Ti interface (Fig. 9 ) from the perspective of energy band. Compared with un-Au@TS-1, the overlap of PDOS (below Fermi level) among the encapsulated Au, framework Ti and bridged O is more obvious in an-Au@TS-1, demonstrating that the possibility for Au-(O)-Ti electronic interactions is increased as the integration of Au-Ti [38,70]. This result also complies with the above charge density difference analyses. After computationally characterized the Au-(O)-Ti electronic interaction, the measurement was also carried out experimentally using XNAES. Fig. 10 describes the fine structures of Au as presented below. In general, the LIII edge peak of the noble metal is in relevant with the electron-transition from 2p to 5d. The intensity represents the d band charge density [40]. Thus, the intensity of LIII edge for Au (11925 eV) decreases in the following order: an-Au@TS-1>un-Au@TS-1>Au foil (Fig. 10). The Au foil exhibits lowest LIII edge intensity due to the fully-occupied 5d10 orbit. An-Au@TS-1 manifests higher LIII edge intensity, demonstrating the loss of more d electrons [71]. This situation rationally suggests an enhanced Au-Ti interfacial interaction in the integrated catalyst of an-Au@TS-1. It is concluded that the Au-Ti integration could enhance their interfacial interaction via bridged oxygen, thereby regulating the local environment of Ti with improved Lewis acidity toward epoxidation application [23,25]. 3.5 Catalytic performances of an-Au@TS-1 Taking the size-effect of Au NPs in consideration [8,11-12,14], the encapsulated catalysts (an-Au@TS-1 and un-Au@TS-1) with an even particle-size of Au (2∼3 nm) were selected to assess the catalytic performances. As present in Fig. 11 , at the same concentration of active sites, an-Au@TS-1 manifests excellent selectivity to PO at 90.2% with high H2 efficiency of 26.7%. This is obviously contrasted versus un-Au@TS-1 (83.4%, 11.8%). The final PO yields of an-Au@TS-1 and un-Au@TS-1 correspond to be 92.9 gPO/kgcat·h and 58.6 gPO/kgcat·h, respectively. Considering the similar size distributions of Au NPs (Fig. 4), such increases in selectivity and H2 efficiency could be assigned to the integration of Au-Ti active sites in an-Au@TS-1, which fundamentally inhibit the decomposition of peroxide species [17,21-22]. Additionally, the supported counterpart (Au/TS-1) shows the worst performances, with PO selectivity, H2 efficiency and PO yield of 81.5%, 9.5% and 40.2 gPO/kgcat·h, respectively (Fig. S4). Meanwhile, detailed product compositions of an-Au@TS-1, un-Au@TS-1, Au/TS-1 are provided in Tab. S3. As mentioned above, there are still some external Ti sites in an-Au@TS-1. The exact number is not easy to characterize directly. Herein, this value could be evaluated on the basis of catalytic data. The two control samples of Au/TS-1 and un-Au@TS-1 contain only external Ti-sites without Au-Ti anchoring relationship, thus eventually presenting similar inferior catalytic properties eventually. For comparison, an-Au@TS-1 possessing well-defined Au-Ti integration shows superior performances with nearly 50% improvement. Considering that all catalyst samples have the same Au-Ti site concentrations, such improvement demonstrates that most Ti sites in an-Au@TS-1 are integrated with the encapsulated Au NPs. That is, minor external framework Ti sites distributing on the surface of zeolitic catalyst in an-Au@TS-1. The catalytic performances were next inspected by adjusting the concentration of Au sites (from 0.25 to 1.0 wt%). Generally, large amount of HOO* species are generated on Au NPs as increasing of Au loading, and then inevitably suffer from decomposition within the Au-Ti interface [17]. This is due to the lack of enough neighboring Ti sites to coordinate with HOO* species in time. Afterward, the as-generated adverse substances (such as H2O or *O−) lead to deep-oxidative degradation of PO on the catalyst [11,18-19,72-73]. At the macro-level, the H2 efficiency as well as PO selectivity would therefore diminish in such circumstances [18]. Nevertheless, this downward trend is remarkably minimized when Au NPs are integrated with framework Ti sites, featuring an increased stability and reactivity of Ti-OOH species [18–19]. The H2 efficiency of an-Au@TS-1 declines from 50.4% to 25.2% while this value of un-Au@TS-1 sharply decrease from 40.3% to 10.3% (Fig. 12 ). Correspondingly, the selectivity of an-Au@TS-1 decays from 90.5% to 83.2%, outperforming those of un-Au@TS-1 (from 83.6% to 75.1%). Au/TS-1 exhibits similar downward trends to those of un-Au@TS-1 (Fig. S5). Due to the wide distribution of Au NPs (4.19 nm, Fig. 4), the H2 efficiencies of Au/TS-1 are always at a lower level (less than 10%). This phenomenon might result from an inefficient generation of HOO*on larger Au NPs [15]. Additionally, the effect of reaction temperature on catalytical performances is also discussed, which could be found in Fig. S6 and its notes. Fig. 13 As the reaction progressed, the catalytic performances gradually decreased and the color of catalyst turned black. This is due to the accumulation of by-products blocking the micropores and covering the active Au-Ti sites (Fig. S7) [19,27,29]. Therefore, the recycling properties of catalysts would be discussed. Prior to the recycling assessment, the used catalyst should be activated by thermal treatment (heating at 500°C for 1 hour under air atmosphere), to remove the coke deposits. The properties of those reused catalysts are illustrated in Fig. S8. The reused an-Au@TS-1 catalyst still has comparable performances to the fresh counterpart, showing slight decreases of PO selectivity and yield (89.1%, 87.4 gPO/kgcat·h). However, the properties of un-Au@TS-1 and Au/TS-1 decline drastically, exhibiting PO selectivity, PO yield of 75.1%, 48.2 gPO/kgcat·h and 69.3%, 20.5 gPO/kgcat·h eventually. This indicates that highly integrated Au-Ti active sites could easily recover and thus manifest better recycling properties. Moreover, the reused an-Au@TS-1 and Au/TS-1 catalysts still exhibit sharp five-finger peaks and homogeneous zeolitic structures, indicating an intact titanium silicate architecture after catalytic recycling (Fig. S9 and S10a-b). However, an obvious peak at 38.2o of Au NPs emerges in the XRD pattern of reused Au/TS-1 catalyst, demonstrating the accumulation of Au NPs. The reused un-Au@TS-1 catalyst shows decreased diffraction peak of MFI topology and broken zeolite morphology (Fig. S9 and S10c). All samples show unchanged Au-Ti composition after recycling evaluation, suggesting the consistency of Au-Ti active sites during the vapor phased processes (Table S1). In conclusion, the inferior recycling performances of un-Au@TS-1 and Au/TS-1 could be attributed to the structural collapse of TS-1 support and the aggregation of Au NPs, respectively. Significantly, the integrated catalyst of an-Au@TS-1 manifests better recycling properties, without any leaching or destruction of active sites. Following the well-known catalytic mechanism [11–16], Ti-OOH species are formed from HOO* in the Au-Ti interface, and then react with propylene to yield PO. Both cases are substantially influenced by the electronic state of peroxide moiety (especially the O-O bond) [18,25]. On one hand, the formation of Ti-OOH species occurs preferentially as the charge density of O-O bond decreases [19]. On the other hand, the lower charge density of Ti-OOH species makes it more stable to defy homolysis, thus serving as more electrophilic epoxidizing-reagent to C=C [11,17,19]. That is, the imbalance of electron density of O-O favors its heterolytic cleavage to insert active oxygen atoms (the oxygen atom in proximity to Ti, termed α-O) into the double bond of propylene [18–19]. The electronic state of Ti-OOH depends on the local environment of Ti sites, in which electron-positive Ti sites help to delocalize the charge density of O-O bond [19,25]. Therefore, an-Au@TS-1 with enhanced electron-positivity of Ti sites exhibits an optimal increment in PO selectivity (90.2%) and H2 efficiency (26.7%), outperforming the other two control samples. The integration of Au-Ti active sites not only fabricates intimate Au-Ti interfaces to promote the quick transfer of HOO* specie, but also regulates the local environment of Ti sites via Au-(O)-Ti interfacial interaction to promote the stability and reactivity of Ti-OOH species. 4 Conclusion In summary, an integrated catalyst of an-Au@TS-1 with a zeolite encapsulation structure was prepared via in situ solvent-free synthesis, with the assistance of tannic acid (TA). Structural characterizations show that an-Au@TS-1 exhibits a regular crystallization structure, with uniform Au NPs encapsulated in proximity to the highly dispersed framework Ti sites. TA acting as a bifunctional agent anchors Au-Ti components, thus rendering Au-Ti active sites highly integrated and dispersed. XPS confirms that the Au-Ti electronic interaction in an-Au@TS-1 is enhanced. Meanwhile, the local environment of Ti site (Si-O-Ti bond) is regulated to strengthen the Lewis acidity, as evidenced by Raman spectroscopy and acetonitrile sorption IR. In light of DFT and XANES, the regulation strategy in an-Au@TS-1 catalyst could be explained as: the integration of Au-Ti active sites contributes to intensify the perturbation to the micro-environment of framework Ti sites (Ti-O-Si) through bridged oxygen involved Au-(O)-Ti interfacial interaction, thus improving the Lewis acidity of Ti sites to increase the stability and reactivity of Ti-OOH. There is a concomitant increment in PO selectivity (90.2%) and H2 efficiency (26.7%) when applying the as-prepared an-Au@TS-1 catalyst to vapor phased propylene epoxidation. The results clarify the influence of the local environment of Ti sites upon the catalytically active Ti-OOH species, and then bring forward a sustainable method to develop better Au-Ti catalysts. The proposed methodology could be applicable to construct a wide variety of metal-hetero atom zeolite integrated catalyst systems, with important catalytic applications. coredata.dc:description: The local environment of framework Ti determines the catalytic properties of titanium silicalites (TS-1) for olefin epoxidation. As for the Au/TS-1 catalyst toward vapor phased propylene epoxidation with H2/O2, regulating the framework Ti site from the Au-Ti integration level remains difficult due to the lack of Au-Ti interfacial interaction. To address this issue, an Au-Ti integrated catalyst with a zeolite encapsulation structure was first proposed herein via in situ solvent-free synthesis, exploiting tannic acid as functional agent to anchor the bifunctional components. The as-prepared an-Au@TS-1 catalyst features highly dispersed and integrated Au-Ti active sites, as mutually confirmed by HR-TEM, ICP and UV-vis. Thus, the Au-Ti interfacial interaction is enhanced to regulate the Ti-O-Si micro-environment, thus improving the electronic-positivity of framework Ti to stabilize the active species. Such crucial regulation effects were stepwise elucidated by mutually complementary characterizations including X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS), adsorption infrared spectra (IR), Raman spectroscopy, X-ray near edge structure (XANES) and density functional theory (DFT) simulations. As anticipated, the integrated catalyst an-Au@TS-1 exhibits a concomitant increment in PO selectivity (90.2%) and H2 efficiency (26.7%). The methodology and insights stated herein could guide the rational optimization of Au-Ti catalysts and help unravel the role of tannic acid assisted strategies for various integrated catalyst preparations.
coredata.dc:title: Tannic Acid Assisted Construction of Au-Ti Integrated Catalyst Regulating the Local Environment of Framework Ti toward Propylene Epoxidation under H2/O2
